However, our methods outperform both RM and PRM even in the perturbed setting.
At the end of the evaluation, i.e. after 2â€‹T=642ğ‘‡642T=64 iterations, NOA achieve almost an order of magnitude lower exploitability. This translate to RM needing 20.320.320.3 and 3.63.63.6 times more iterations than NOA and NPRM respectively to achieve the same exploitability, see Table 1(a).
Finally, we can see that NPRM is indeed able to minimize regret far above the number of iterations it has been trained to do so (see TheoremÂ 1). Perhaps surprisingly, the same is true for NOA.

Our results, presented in FigureÂ 3 show our method can outperform (P)RM even in a sequential setting.
Specifically, even in the perturbed setting after 2â€‹T2ğ‘‡2T steps, it would take 73.7, resp. 16-times more steps for RM to reach the final exploitability of NOA, resp. NPRM (see Table 1(b)).
